fepitre-bot
r4.3-testing

Template kicksecure-18 4.3.0-202512071252 for Qubes OS r4.3, see comments below …for details and build status. If you're release manager, you can issue GPG-inline signed command (depending on template): * `Upload-template r4.3 kicksecure-18 4.3.0-202512071252 templates-itl` (available 5 days from now) * `Upload-template r4.3 kicksecure-18 4.3.0-202512071252 templates-community` (available 5 days from now) Above commands will work only if package in testing repository isn't superseded by newer version. For more information on how to test this update, please take a look at https://www.qubes-os.org/doc/testing/#updates.

item.title: Kicksecure Qubes Template Development - Qubes Integration
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues

`pipewire.socket` unexpectedly runs in `minimal-netvm` and `minimal-usbvm` but should not

opened 04:05PM - 05 Dec 25 UTC
adrelanos
P: default

### Qubes OS release R4.3rc3 ### Brief summary `pipewire.socket` should not b…e activated in `minimal-netvm` and `minimal-usbvm`. This is already the case for `pipewire.service`. But this is not yet done for `pipewire.socket` but probably should be. ### Steps to reproduce It's a Kicksecure 18 VM but I don't see why this wouldn't happen with a Debian (13) based VM either. `systemctl --user is-system-running` ``` degraded zsh: exit 1 systemctl --user is-system-running ``` `systemctl --user status pipewire.socket` ``` × pipewire.socket - PipeWire Multimedia System Sockets Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.socket; enabled; preset: enabled) Active: failed (Result: trigger-limit-hit) since Duration: 182ms Invocation: 2b6371b2762f419fbf8144db13f51c15 Triggers: ● pipewire.service Listen: /run/user/1000/pipewire-0 (Stream) /run/user/1000/pipewire-0-manager (Stream) sys-net systemd[1212]: Listening on pipewire.socket - PipeWire Multimedia System Sockets. sys-net systemd[1212]: pipewire.socket: Trigger limit hit, refusing further activation. sys-net systemd[1212]: pipewire.socket: Failed with result 'trigger-limit-hit'. zsh: exit 3 systemctl --user status pipewire.socket ``` `systemctl --no-pager --user status pipewire.service` ``` ○ pipewire.service - PipeWire Multimedia Service Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.service; enabled; preset: enabled) Drop-In: /usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.service.d └─30_qubes.conf, 40_minimal.conf Active: inactive (dead) TriggeredBy: × pipewire.socket Condition: start condition unmet at └─ ConditionPathExists=!/var/run/qubes-service/minimal-netvm was not met sys-net systemd[1212]: pipewire.service - PipeWire Multimedia Service was skipped because of an unmet condition check (ConditionPathExists=!/var/run/qubes-ser…minimal-netvm). Hint: Some lines were ellipsized, use -l to show in full. zsh: exit 3 systemctl --no-pager --user status pipewire.service ``` ### Expected behavior No such errors. ### Actual behavior Above errors. ### Additional information `/usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.service.d/40_minimal.conf` exists. And makes sense. That's for `pipewire.service`. Should the same file be placed in `/usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.socket.d/40_minimal.conf` for `pipewire.socket`? (And maybe equivalent for `/usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.service.d/30_qubes.conf`) ---- [1] `cat /usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.service.d/40_minimal.conf` ``` [Unit] ConditionPathExists=!/var/run/qubes-service/minimal-netvm ConditionPathExists=!/var/run/qubes-service/minimal-usbvm ``` `cat /usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.service.d/30_qubes.conf` ``` [Unit] # Avoid pipewire in root's session to not steal user's connection to the audiovm ConditionUser=!root ``` ---- This is also an issue because a new version of `systemcheck` in Kicksecure will report this issue. ``` [WARNING] [systemcheck] systemd 'user' units check result: One or more units failed to load. A possible system issue was detected. There is no need to panic. This is not a serious security problem. However, it may impact other system checks. Some systemd 'user' units may be stuck in a failed, activating, or deactivating state. Output of 'systemctl --user --no-pager --no-block --state=failed,activating,deactivating list-units':: ######################################## UNIT LOAD ACTIVE SUB DESCRIPTION * pipewire.socket loaded failed failed PipeWire Multimedia System Sockets Legend: LOAD -> Reflects whether the unit definition was properly loaded. ACTIVE -> The high-level unit activation state, i.e. generalization of SUB. SUB -> The low-level unit activation state, values depend on unit type. 1 loaded units listed. ######################################## To check manually: 1. Open a terminal. (dom0 -> Start Menu -> ServiceVM: sys-net -> Terminal) 2. Run: systemctl --user --no-pager --no-block --state=failed,activating,deactivating list-units If you know what you are doing, feel free to disable this check. Create a file /etc/systemcheck.d/50_user.conf and add: systemcheck_skip_functions+=" check_services_do " ``` ---- `systemctl --user is-system-running` outputting `degraded` might cause issues elsewhere in Qubes (guess). `/etc/qubes-rpc/qubes.WaitForSession` does `systemctl --user --wait --quiet is-system-running`. Related: * https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues/issues/10384 ---- The solution might be as simple as the equivalent of: ``` sudo mkdir /usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.socket.d/ sudo cp /usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.service.d/* /usr/lib/systemd/user/pipewire.socket.d/ ```

item.title: Kicksecure Qubes Template Development - Qubes Integration
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues

Dom0 (internal) tool to copy a file into specific place in a VM

opened 01:17PM - 05 Dec 25 UTC
marmarek
P: default

> > While at this... Would it be possible to use a different path other than `/h…ome` please? Because that may introduce a risk in context of user-sysmaint-split (and maybe also in context of home noexec). > > This is the path where qvm-copy puts the file, and copy source (intentionally) has no influence on the directory. While dom0 could use a different mechanism to send the file (even naive `qvm-run ... 'cat > ...'`), that would likely lead to other issues. > > If there was a dom0 wrapper... > > qvm-copy-to-path dest_vmname dom0-source-file-or-folder vm-destination-file-or-folder > > Then `qubes-dist-upgrade` could conveniently use it to install the file to a more appropriate location such as in `/usr/bin`. That would be easier to read than the `qvm-run ... 'cat > ...'` syntax. > > A dom0 tool `qvm-copy-to-path` would be nice to have anyhow for all sorts of system administration tasks. Or at least as an internal tool if not user facing. _Originally posted by @adrelanos in [#10437](https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues/issues/10437#issuecomment-3616561841)_

Read full topic

github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues

Broken Kicksecure StandaloneVM if upgraded to Kicksecure 18 (debain 13)

opened 10:58AM - 01 Dec 25 UTC
Nurmagoz
P: default

[How to file a helpful issue](https://www.qubes-os.org/doc/issue-tracking/) ###… Qubes OS release 4.3rc3 ### Brief summary User with StandaloneVM based on debian 12 morphed into KS 17 cant upgrade to KS 18. ### Steps to reproduce - Install debian 12 - Add KS repository - Install `kicksecure-cli` and `kicksecure-qubes-cli` packages (not gui/lxqt/xfce/full) - Install `user-sysmaint-split` package - After that, disable/comment out KS repo - Change debian repos from bookworm to trixie, and qubes from 4.2 bookworm to 4.3 trixie (if not done already) - Update the repos and Upgrade with this command `apt --no-install-recommends full-upgrade` to avoid extra not meant to be installed software/firmware, everything will go ok even if using `apt autoremove "--purge" && apt autoclean` - Enable KS repo and switch it to trixie - Update the repos `apt update` - run `release-upgrade` - If after that `apt autoremove "--purge" && apt autoclean` will be used, it will lead to unusable/broken KS (clearly seen after reboot). ### Logs - Upgrading KS with `release-upgrade` log: [upgradelog.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/23851720/upgradelog.txt) - Using `apt autoremove "--purge" && apt autoclean` ``` [root ~]# apt update && apt full-upgrade && apt autoremove --purge && apt autoclean Hit:1 https://deb.kicksecure.com trixie-testers InRelease Get:2 https://deb.qubes-os.org/r4.3/vm trixie InRelease [4,735 B] Hit:3 tor+https://fasttrack.debian.net/debian-fasttrack trixie-fasttrack InRelease Hit:4 tor+https://deb.debian.org/debian trixie InRelease Hit:5 tor+https://fasttrack.debian.net/debian-fasttrack trixie-backports-staging InRelease Hit:6 tor+https://deb.debian.org/debian trixie-updates InRelease Hit:7 tor+https://deb.debian.org/debian trixie-backports InRelease Hit:8 tor+https://deb.debian.org/debian-security trixie-security InRelease Fetched 4,735 B in 1s (3,167 B/s) All packages are up to date. item.title: Kicksecure Qubes Template Development - Qubes Integration
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues

Qube Manager crashes when attempting to view settings for a qube containing PCI devices that no longer exist

opened 12:54AM - 17 Nov 25 UTC
ArrayBolt3
C: Qubes GUI tools P: default needs diagnosis affects-4.3

[How to file a helpful issue](https://www.qubes-os.org/doc/issue-tracking/) ###… Qubes OS release R4.3 ### Brief summary Yesterday, I ended up moving my testing Qubes OS installation from a fairly recent Intel-based system (13th gen CPU) to a somewhat older one (11th gen CPU). The USB controller in this system is different than the one in the previous system, and so sys-usb would not start since it couldn't pass through a non-existent PCI device. To resolve this, I assumed I'd be able to open Qube Manager, select sys-usb, click Settings, then go to the Devices tab and remove the non-existent device. Unfortunately, upon clicking the "Settings" button, Qube Manager crashed. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Install Qubes OS R4.3 on a machine with a particular generation of Intel CPU (I assume AMD CPUs will show the same problems). 2. Boot the installed system once, verify sys-usb and sys-net start, then shut the system down properly. 3. Move the drive from the system where you installed it to some other system with a different generation of Intel CPU. 4. Boot the installed system. sys-usb should not start. 5. Attempt to start sys-usb. You should see an error about a PCI device not being available. 6. In dom0, open xfce4-terminal, and run `qubes-qube-manager`. 7. Click on sys-usb. 8. Click the Settings button. ### Expected behavior VM settings window appears. ### Actual behavior Qube Manager crashes, and a Python exception is printed in the terminal. ### Additional information I was able to recover from this state by running `sudo qvm-pci unassign sys-usb`. After this, the settings window would open normally for sys-usb.

item.title: Kicksecure Qubes Template Development - Qubes Integration
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-video-companion

Add privleap support

main ← ArrayBolt3:arraybolt3/privleap
opened 01:52AM - 18 Nov 25 UTC
ArrayBolt3
+34 -3

Under Kicksecure and Whonix 18, sudo is no longer executable by "normal" users, …and is only accessible when booting in a special "sysmaint mode". This prevents QVC from loading v4l2loopback. Kicksecure introduces a more limited escalation framework, privleap, which can be used by explicitly authorized normal users (including the `user` account present by default in most AppVMs). Add a privleap rule to QVC that allows users in the sudo, privleap, and qubes groups to load the v4l2loopback module on demand. If sudo is not executable or execution of sudo fails, try to use privleap instead. Fixes: https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues/issues/10163

item.title: Kicksecure Qubes Template Development - Qubes Integration
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues

qubes.WaitForSession emits an error `Failed to connect to user scope bus via local transport: $DBUS_SESSION_BUS_ADDRESS and $XDG_RUNTIME_DIR not defined`

opened 01:40AM - 04 Nov 25 UTC
ArrayBolt3
C: core P: default needs diagnosis affects-4.3

[How to file a helpful issue](https://www.qubes-os.org/doc/issue-tracking/) ###… Qubes OS release R4.3 ### Brief summary In all templates (at least the ones I've tried; debian-13-xfce, fedora-42-xfce, and whonix-gateway-18), there is an error message in the output of `sudo journalctl --boot` matching the title. This appears to be coming from `/etc/qubes-rpc/qubes.WaitForSession`. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Boot `fedora-42-xfce`. 2. Run `sudo journalctl --boot` 3. Search for `Failed to connect to user scope bus` 4. See error 5. Run `sudo vim /etc/qubes-rpc/qubes.WaitForSession` 6. Replace the line `systemctl --user --wait --quiet is-system-running` with the following: ``` logger "$$: $(id)" systemctl --user --wait --quiet is-system-running || { logger '$$: failed here' } logger "$$: made it" ``` 7. Reboot the template. 8. Run `sudo journalctl --boot` in the template. 9. Search for `failed here`, and observe that the service is failing when called as `root`, but succeeds when called as `user`, based on the logger output from earlier. ### Expected behavior `qubes.WaitForSession` should never emit any errors. ### Actual behavior `qubes.WaitForSession` is emitting the aforementioned error when called as `root`. ### Additional information I tried making the following modification to `qubes.WaitForSession` in `whonis-gateway-18`, but while this did fix the error message, it also made it so that if one attempts to launch a GUI app in the qube while it is not yet booted, the qube will boot without issues, but the app will never launch. Subsequent attempts to launch GUI apps succeed. ``` logger "$(id)" logger "trying... $$" if [ "$(id -u)" = '0' ]; then systemctl --wait --quiet is-system-running else systemctl --user --wait --quiet is-system-running fi logger "made it! $$" ``` This showed that it took about 9 or 10 seconds from the time that `root` showed a `trying: PID` message to the time that `root` showed a `made it! PID` message (with the PID values matching in both locations). The first GUI app I attempted to launch never showed up, not even after twenty seconds. The following modification seems to get rid of the error message *and* keep the previous behavior, but I'm not sure if it's correct since it means that `qubes.WaitForSession` may return before the system is "fully booted" (which is what the current, unmodified code does also): ``` if [ "$(id -u)" = '0' ]; then exit 0 else systemctl --user --wait --quiet is-system-running fi ```

Read full topic

item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues

builderv2(-github?): fetch relevant template-* components before template build

opened 09:00PM - 21 Oct 25 UTC
marmarek
C: builder P: default C: infrastructure diagnosed affects-4.3

[How to file a helpful issue](https://www.qubes-os.org/doc/issue-tracking/) ###… Qubes OS release R4.3 ### Brief summary When handling the "Build template ...", the builder assumes it has up to date source fetched. This is a reasonable assumption for most components, as there is a webhook that notifies builders when stuff gets pushed to QubesOS org. But that doesn't work for components from other orgs (like Whonix or Kicksecure). ### Steps to reproduce Try to build template just after pushing something to https://github.com/kicksecure/qubes-template-kicksecure ### Expected behavior New repository content is fetched and build works ### Actual behavior https://github.com/QubesOS/updates-status/issues/6097 ### Additional information There are two workarounds possible: - configure webhook in those other repositories too (I don't like it, as it makes configuration spread even more - harder to manage different community templates) - push something (can be any branch) to same-named repository in QubesOS org, to trigger source fetch - currently used workaround

item.title: Kicksecure Qubes Template Development - Qubes Integration
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues

On first use, DispVM console has strange control character sequences preloaded into the `login:` prompt, causing the first authentication attempt to fail

opened 03:56PM - 05 Oct 25 UTC
ArrayBolt3
P: default

[How to file a helpful issue](https://www.qubes-os.org/doc/issue-tracking/) ###… Qubes OS release R4.3 ### Brief summary When using the "Open console in qube" feature of Qube Manager to open a DispVM console for a qube, the character sequence `^[[24;1R^[[24;80R^[[24;1R^[[24;80R` is pre-populated in the `login:` prompt. If I ignore this weird sequence of characters, enter the username `user`, and press Enter, I immediately get the message `Authentication failure`. A new login prompt then appears that doesn't have this weird sequence preloaded into it. Typing `user` into that prompt and pressing Enter results in a successful login. I can also use Backspace to erase most of the character sequence, then type `user` and press Enter to log in successfully the first time. ### Steps to reproduce * In Qube Manager, click any qube (doesn't seem to matter which, I can reproduce this on a Fedora 42 AppVM, a Whonix-Workstation 18 AppVM, and the debian-13-xfce template), click "Start/Resume", then click "Open console in qube". * Look at the `login:` prompt before attempting to log in. * Type `user` and press Enter. * After the authentication failure, type `user` again and press Enter. * Shut down the qube. * In Qube Manager, click any qube, then click "Start/Resume", then click "Open console in qube". * When the `login:` prompt occurs, press and hold Backspace until as many characters as you can erase are erased. * Type `user` and press Enter. ### Expected behavior No character sequence should be preloaded into the `login:` prompt. Typing `user` and pressing Enter should work to log in the first time. ### Actual behavior The character sequence mentioned previously is preloaded into the `login:` prompt. Typing `user` and pressing Enter fails the first time but works the second time. When trying to erase the character sequence, it is possible to erase *most* of it, but not the entirety of it. Despite this, typing `user` and pressing Enter after erasing as much of the sequence as possible still works to log in. ### Additional information n/a

item.title: Kicksecure Qubes Template Development - Qubes Integration
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues

`XDG_DATA_DIRS` is reset to a minimal list of directories in applications opened from the Qubes app menu, breaking default application resolution

opened 03:43PM - 05 Oct 25 UTC
ArrayBolt3
P: default

[How to file a helpful issue](https://www.qubes-os.org/doc/issue-tracking/) ###… Qubes OS release R4.3 ### Brief summary Whonix modifies the `XDG_DATA_DIRS` environment variable via scripts in `/etc/profile.d` (and `/etc/zprofile.d`). These modifications allow Whonix to customize things such as default application associations. These changes are picked up by Qubes OS and do appear in login shells, but somehow `XDG_DATA_DIRS` (and to my awareness, *only* `XDG_DATA_DIRS`) is reset to a "minimal" set of directories in applications that are opened from the Qubes app menu. This results in all of Whonix's file association settings usually being ignored. ### Steps to reproduce * Install a Whonix-Workstation 18 template. * Create an AppVM based off this template, and launch QTerminal in it. * Run `echo $XDG_DATA_DIRS`. * Open Qube Manager, select the Whonix-Workstation 18 AppVM, and click "Open console in qube". * Log in as "user" (no password required), then run `echo $XDG_DATA_DIRS`. ### Expected behavior In both instances, `echo $XDG_DATA_DIRS` should output `/usr/share/usability-misc/xdg-override/:/usr/share/anon-apps-config/share/:/usr/share/open-link-confirmation/xdg-override:/var/lib/flatpak/exports/share:/usr/local/share/:/usr/share/` or similar. ### Actual behavior In the DispVM console, `echo $XDG_DATA_DIRS` outputs the expected value, but in QTerminal, the returned string is `/home/user/.local/share/flatpak/exports/share:/var/lib/flatpak/exports/share:/usr/local/share/:/usr/share/`. ### Additional information This is contributing to an issue, where clicking on the Qubes Domains widget in the system tray, hovering over a Whonix-Workstation 18 qube, and clicking "Open File Manager" opens Catfish File Search rather than PCManFM-Qt. Whonix ships a file at `/usr/share/usability-misc/xdg-override/applications/defaults.list` that is supposed to set the default application for `inode/directory` to `pcmanfm-qt.desktop`. Right now that file is out-of-date and is pointing to `thunar.desktop` instead, but even when it is changed to point to `pcmanfm-qt.desktop`, Catfish still opens when clicking this button in the widget. Running `xdg-open $HOME` in QTerminal also opens Catfish. However, running `DISPLAY=:0 xdg-open $HOME` in the DispVM console opens PCManFM-Qt as expected. (Granted, it looks awful because `QT_QPA_PLATFORMTHEME='lxqt'` is strangely not being set properly, but that's an unrelated issue.) The only thing I see in Qubes' code that looks like it modifies `XDG_DATA_DIRS` is https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-core-agent-linux/blob/bffc6e0d0df3874781c0feda8297be5063fabba1/qubes-rpc/qubes.StartApp. Could this be part of the issue?

Read full topic

item.title: Kicksecure Qubes Template Development - Qubes Integration
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-core-agent-linux

Add qubes-core-agent-pcmanfm-qt integration package

main ← ArrayBolt3:arraybolt3/pcmanfm-qt
opened 10:29PM - 26 Sep 25 UTC
ArrayBolt3
+104 -2

This will be used by Whonix 18, since our default file manager will be PCManFM-Q…t. Some rough spots that may need ironed out: * This reuses the `qvm-actions.sh` script from qubes-core-agent-thunar. At the moment this is done by simply copying `qubes-rpc/thunar/qvm-actions.sh` into the `qubes-core-agent-pcmanfm-qt` package, which is horrible. Duplication isn't a workable solution though because the package build procedure installs all of the files from all of the agent packages at once and then splits them into binary packages, and both `qubes-core-agent-thunar` and `qubes-core-agent-pcmanfm-qt` place `qvm-actions.sh` at the same location on the filesystem. This shared location also means that `qubes-core-agent-thunar` and `qubes-core-agent-pcmanfm-qt` have to conflict with each other. Ideally this script would be located in some shared package, but I'm not sure there's an appropriate one already existing, and I'm not sure making a new package shared only between `qubes-core-agent-thunar` and `qubes-core-agent-pcmanfm-qt` is warranted when this is just one script file. * The .desktop files used to define the actions that can be performed on each file have to use mime types to specify what files those actions are intended to match. As it turns out, there is no good way to express "match all files regardless of type, but do not match directories" as a mime type or combination thereof, so instead we currently just use "match everything" globs even on actions that don't work on directories, then display a popup warning if a directory is detected. I do not know of any good alternative to this. * Because file types are specified by mime type rather than file name extension, there is likely some introspection done on the files to determine what actions to display. I have no idea how secure Qt's mime type detection routines are, or if pcmanfm-qt even uses those routines for mime type detection as opposed to using something like `file`. I also don't know if there's a way to turn that detection logic off, and even if there was, that would break the ability to do things like only showing "Convert PDF in disposable qube" for PDF files.

item.title: Kicksecure Qubes Template Development - Qubes Integration
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues

decide availability of Kicksecure, and Whonix 18 (Debian trixie based) on Qubes R4.2 versus R4.3

opened 08:40AM - 13 Sep 25 UTC
adrelanos
P: default

Kicksecure, and Whonix 18 (Debian trixie based) are in development. As a develop…er, I guesstimate that hopefully a release can be made within the next approximately 2 weeks. (Please don't quote me on it.) Would it be sufficient if Kicksecure, and Whonix 18 are made available for Qubes R4.3 only? I.e. would be it be OK if Kicksecure, and Whonix 18 would not be made available for Qubes R4.2? That would simplify development, maintenance, testing. Primarily, pull request https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-core-admin-addon-whonix/pull/21 has been merged for Qubes R4.3 but we didn't backport it to Qubes R4.2 yet. This would cause [qrexec `sdwdate.ConnectCheck` denied messages](https://forum.qubes-os.org/t/whonix-18-denied-sdwdate-connectcheck/36098) on Qubes R4.2. What's the guestimate for the Qubes R4.3 release date? Related tickets: * https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues/issues/10020 * https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues/issues/7447 Related: * [Kicksecure Support Schedule](https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/About#Support_Schedule) * [Whonix Support Schedule](https://www.whonix.org/wiki/About#Support_Schedule)
